text: Understanding Python super() and init methods
From the looks of it, both child classes can be created just fine.
Im curious as to what difference there actually is in this code:

code:
class Base(object):
    def __init__(self):
        print "Base created"

class ChildA(Base):
    def __init__(self):
        Base.__init__(self)

class ChildB(Base):
    def __init__(self):
        super(ChildB, self).__init__()

print ChildA(),ChildB()
